questions.question_text_1: Consider three components of a todo list app based on an MVC architecture.  A - stores a list of all the tasks that the user has submitted along with attributes like completion status. B - can display which tasks were completed, which tasks are pending, receive new tasks from the user etc. C - can set a task in the list of tasks as completed, add a new task to the list of tasks, delete old tasks, retrieve a list of pending tasks and so on.  Given the above capabilities of the different components, choose the correct option:
question_texts: Consider three components of a todo list app based on an MVC architecture.  A - stores a list of all the tasks that the user has submitted along with attributes like completion status. B - can display which tasks were completed, which tasks are pending, receive new tasks from the user etc. C - can set a task in the list of tasks as completed, add a new task to the list of tasks, delete old tasks, retrieve a list of pending tasks and so on.  Given the above capabilities of the different components, choose the correct option:

options.option_text: model - A, view - B, controller - C
model - B, view - A, controller - C
model - C, view - B, controller - A
model - A, view - C, controller - B

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is/are correct?  Statement 1: In client-server architecture, the client and the server MUST be on separate machines Statement 2: In peer-to-peer architecture, the network is always more fault-tolerant
question_texts: Which of the following statements is/are correct?  Statement 1: In client-server architecture, the client and the server MUST be on separate machines Statement 2: In peer-to-peer architecture, the network is always more fault-tolerant

options.option_text: Both statement 1 and statement 2 are correct.
Statement 1 is correct but statement 2 is incorrect.
Statement 2 is correct but statement 1 is incorrect.
Neither statement 1 nor statement 2 is correct.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a client ‘C’ and a server ‘S’, separated by distance ‘D’ are connected by a fictitious medium in which the speed of light is ‘v’ m/sec. If ‘N’ is the number of consecutive requests that can made in a second by the client ‘C’ (i.e A new request can be made only after receiving the response from the previous request.), Which of the following changes would double the number ‘N’?
question_texts: Consider a client ‘C’ and a server ‘S’, separated by distance ‘D’ are connected by a fictitious medium in which the speed of light is ‘v’ m/sec. If ‘N’ is the number of consecutive requests that can made in a second by the client ‘C’ (i.e A new request can be made only after receiving the response from the previous request.), Which of the following changes would double the number ‘N’?

options.option_text: A change of medium where the speed of light is v/2 m/sec.
A change of medium where the speed of light is 2v m/sec.
Reduce the distance between C and S from D to D/2.
Increase the distance between C and S from D to 2D.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following sorting algorithm which sorts any given unsorted array of numbers in ascending order. What would be its time complexity? (Assume appending and deleting an element from an array does not affect time complexity)  Step 1: Create an empty array. Step 2: Find the element in the unsorted array with the minimum value. Step 3: Append this element to the array created in step 1. Step 4: Delete this element from the unsorted array. Step 5: Repeat steps 1 to 4 until the unsorted array is empty.
question_texts: Consider the following sorting algorithm which sorts any given unsorted array of numbers in ascending order. What would be its time complexity? (Assume appending and deleting an element from an array does not affect time complexity)  Step 1: Create an empty array. Step 2: Find the element in the unsorted array with the minimum value. Step 3: Append this element to the array created in step 1. Step 4: Delete this element from the unsorted array. Step 5: Repeat steps 1 to 4 until the unsorted array is empty.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development 1"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **1. Core Topics & Concepts** ### **A. Software Architecture & Design Patterns** #### **1. MVC (Model-View-Controller) Architecture** - **Model**: Manages data, logic, and rules (e.g., stores tasks in a to-do app). - **View**: Displays data to the user (e.g., UI showing pending/completed tasks). - **Controller**: Handles user input, updates the model, and refreshes the view. - **Example**: - **Model (A)**: Stores task list and completion status. - **View (B)**: Displays tasks (completed/pending) and accepts new tasks. - **Controller (C)**: Adds/deletes tasks, marks tasks as completed. #### **2. Client-Server vs. Peer-to-Peer Architecture** - **Client-Server**: - Clients request services; servers provide them. - **Misconception**: Clients and servers **do not** need to be on separate machines. - **Peer-to-Peer (P2P)**: - All nodes are equal (can act as client/server). - **Fault Tolerance**: Not inherently more fault-tolerant (depends on implementation). #### **3. Web Components** - Custom HTML elements using JavaScript (e.g., ``). - **Key APIs**: - `CustomElementRegistry.define()`: Registers a new custom element. - Shadow DOM: Encapsulates component styles/scripts. --- ### **B. Databases** #### **1. Relational Databases** - **Terminology**: - **Column**: Stores a **single field** (e.g., `name`). - **Row**: Stores a **single entry** (e.g., one user’s data). - **Constraints**: - `PRIMARY KEY`: Uniquely identifies a row. - `UNIQUE`: Ensures no duplicate values in a column. - `NOT NULL`: Column cannot have `NULL` values. #### **2. SQLAlchemy (Flask-SQLAlchemy)** - **Model Definition**: ```python class Employee(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) name = db.Column(db.String(50), unique=True, nullable=False) ``` - **Querying**: ```python employees = Employee.query.filter_by(gender="Male").all() ``` #### **3. Entity-Relationship (ER) Diagrams** - **One-to-Many**: - Example: One `Employee` can have many `Salary_Slip`s. - **Inferences**: - A salary slip **must** belong to one employee (foreign key constraint). - An employee **can exist** without salary slips. --- ### **C. Version Control (Git)** #### **1. Key Commands** | Command | Description | |----------------------------------|----------------------------------------------| | `git rm --cached ` | Remove from staging but keep locally. | | `git add ` | Stage a file for commit. | | `git commit -m "message"` | Commit staged changes. | #### **2. Branching & Merging** - **Branches**: Isolate features/bugfixes. - **Merge Conflicts**: Resolve manually when Git cannot auto-merge. --- ### **D. Web Development (Flask & Jinja2)** #### **1. Flask Routing & Request Handling** - **Route Decorators**: ```python @app.route('/user/') def show_user(username): return f"Hello {username}!" ``` - **HTTP Methods**: - `GET`: Retrieve data. - `POST`: Submit data. - `PUT`: Update data. #### **2. Jinja2 Templating** - **Loops**: ```jinja2 {% for item in items %}
  • {{ item }}
    • {% endfor %} ``` - **Conditionals**: ```jinja2 {% if user %} Welcome, {{ user }}! {% endif %} ``` - **Macros**: Reusable template snippets. ```jinja2 {% macro render_user(user) %}
    {{ user.name }}
    {% endmacro %} ``` #### **3. Flask-RESTful** - **Resource Classes**: ```python class Todo(Resource): def get(self, todo_id): return {"task": "Buy groceries"} ``` - **Marshalling**: Format API responses. ```python fields = {"id": fields.Integer, "name": fields.String} @marshal_with(fields) def get(self): return user ``` --- ### **E. Testing & Debugging** #### **1. Unit Testing (Pytest)** - **Assertions**: ```python def test_add(): assert add(2, 3) == 5 ``` - **Test Outputs**: - `PASS`: Test succeeds. - `FAIL`: Test assertion fails. - `ERROR`: Test crashes. #### **2. Test Coverage Types** | Type | Description | Example | |--------------------|----------------------------------------------|----------------------------------| | **Function** | Every function is called. | `foo()` is invoked. | | **Statement** | Every line of code is executed. | All `if` branches are tested. | | **Branch** | Every `if/else` path is tested. | `foo(1,1)` and `foo(1,0)`. | | **Condition** | Every boolean sub-expression is tested. | `(x > 0) && (y > 0)`. | #### **3. Logging** - **Levels**: `DEBUG`, `INFO`, `WARNING`, `ERROR`, `CRITICAL`. - **Example**: ```python import logging logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO) logging.info("User logged in") ``` --- ### **F. Networking & Performance** #### **1. Bandwidth & Data Consumption** - **Formula**: ``` Total Data (GB) = Bandwidth (Mbps) × Time (hours) × 3600 (s) / (8 × 1024³) (GB) ``` - **Example**: - 8 Mbps × 8 hours = **5.216 GB** (but answer was **6.52 GB** due to rounding). #### **2. Latency & Throughput** - **Round-Trip Time (RTT)**: ``` RTT = 2 × Distance / Speed of Light ``` - **Doubling Requests/Second (N)**: - Halve RTT (e.g., double speed `v → 2v` or halve distance `D → D/2`). --- ### **G. Mathematics for Computing** #### **1. Number Base Conversion** - **Decimal Equivalent**: - \(113_a = 1 \times a^2 + 1 \times a^1 + 3 \times a^0\) - \(365_b = 3 \times b^2 + 6 \times b^1 + 5 \times b^0\) - **Example**: - For \(a = 16\), \(b = 8\): - \(113_{16} = 275_{10}\) - \(365_8 = 245_{10}\) - \(275 > 245\) → Valid. #### **2. Time Complexity** - **Selection Sort-like Algorithm**: - **Steps**: 1. Find min element in unsorted array. 2. Append to new array. 3. Repeat until unsorted array is empty. - **Complexity**: \(O(N^2)\) (nested loops). --- ## **2. Key Equations** | Concept | Equation | |-----------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **Data Consumption** | \(\text{Data (GB)} = \frac{\text{Bandwidth (Mbps)} \times \text{Time (s)}}{8 \times 1024^3}\) | | **Round-Trip Time** | \(\text{RTT} = \frac{2 \times \text{Distance}}{\text{Speed of Light}}\) | | **Base Conversion** | \(N_a = d_n \times a^n + \dots + d_0 \times a^0\) | | **Time Complexity** | \(O(N^2)\) for nested loops (e.g., selection sort). | --- ## **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **Graph 1: MVC Architecture** ```mermaid graph TD A[User] -->|Interacts with| B[View] B -->|Renders| C[Model] C -->|Updates| B A -->|Sends Input| D[Controller] D -->|Modifies| C D -->|Refreshes| B ``` ### **Graph 2: Git Workflow** ```mermaid graph LR A[Working Directory] -->|git add| B[Staging Area] B -->|git commit| C[Local Repository] C -->|git push| D[Remote Repository] D -->|git pull| C ``` ### **Graph 3: Flask Request Lifecycle** ```mermaid graph TD A[Client] -->|HTTP Request| B[Flask App] B -->|Route Matching| C[View Function] C -->|Processes Request| D[Model/Database] D -->|Returns Data| C C -->|Renders Template| E[Jinja2] E -->|HTML Response| A ``` ### **Graph 4: Testing Pyramid** ```mermaid graph TD A[Unit Tests] -->|Fast, Isolated| B[Integration Tests] B -->|Component Interaction| C[End-to-End Tests] C -->|Full System| D[Manual Testing] ``` ### **Graph 5: Client-Server vs P2P** ```mermaid graph LR subgraph Client-Server A[Client 1] -->|Request| B[Server] C[Client 2] -->|Request| B B -->|Response| A B -->|Response| C end subgraph Peer-to-Peer D[Peer 1] <--->|Share| E[Peer 2] E <--->|Share| F[Peer 3] end ``` ### **Graph 6: SQLAlchemy Relationships** ```mermaid graph LR A[Employee] -->|One-to-Many| B[Salary_Slip] B -->|Foreign Key| A ``` ### **Graph 7: Jinja2 Template Inheritance** ```mermaid graph TD A[base.html] -->|extends| B[home.html] A -->|defines blocks| C[content] B -->|fills block| C ```
